segments.text: In the very first video of chapter 3,
I showed this example when talking about oscillating
motion in general.
What if what I want to model is some type of undulating wave
pattern?
So by the end of this particular video,
I want to have something just like this example for you
to be able to work with.
And where I'm going to start from,
however, is this example, the one
that I ended with in the last video, that
is one single dot or circle oscillating up and down
the vertical axis of a P5 canvas.
So how am I going to do that?
Well, if I wanted to graph a static wave, what I would do
is I would consider in a P5 canvas every x pixel
to be an angle value.
And then I would calculate the sine of that angle
and map that to some y value.
And I could say begin shape, end shape, vertex, vertex, vertex,
and connect them all.
I have an example I'll link to in the video description that
does exactly that.
But I'm going to do this in a slightly different way.
Ultimately, it's the same thing in the end,
but I want to start with it in motion.
I want to think about this one dot as an object oscillating up
and down.
And then I want to make an array of those dots.
And I want them all to oscillate up and down.
Now, there's a lot of things you could do here just
by starting to vary the period and frequency of each one
of these dots moving up and down.
I almost want to just do that right now.
Let's go ahead.
I'm going to do that right now.
I'm going to start by taking the single angle variable
and make it an array called angles.
Then it will be useful for me to keep track of the size.
I'll just use a variable for the radius
of each one of those circles.
And then I need to know how many circles
fit across the entire width.
And that should be an integer value.
So I will just take off the decimal place.
Then I can write a loop to create
all the elements of the array, all the angles for every spot.
Now, instead of just drawing one circle here at x equals 0,
I want to draw many of them, a circle
for every single spot in that array of angles.
Let me comment out the incrementing the angle
for a moment right now.
And I need to figure out where is
the x position of every circle.
To do this, I'll use the map function again.
And remember, I have translated to the center here.
So I want all of the circles to be between negative 300
and 300 because the canvas is 600 pixels wide.
Oh, and this, of course, now, very, very important.
It's not sine of the angle anymore.
It's sine of angles index i.
And now you can see I have now drawn many circles
across the horizontal axis.
If I were to bring back incrementing the angle,
do it inside the loop, angles index i plus equal angle v.
And the line should also correspond to x.
We can now see I have all of the circles oscillating up
and down.
They're all oscillating at exactly the same period
with exactly the same amplitude.
As an exercise, you might start to think about, oh,
how could I vary the amplitude of each of these?
Or how could I vary the period?
Well, let's vary the period or the frequency
just by having an array of these angle v values.
So now all of them have a completely random value.
So they're all offset just with no logic to them whatsoever.
I could do something like, oh, let me say i divided by 10.
Oh, that's too much.
I divided by 100.
Now you can see their periods have a relative relationship
to each other.
They're faster on the right side, slower on the left.
So they'll get out of those sort of like end up
in these with these different patterns.
You can see the one on the left is always just never changing
because I started at 0.
So probably would make sense for me to say, oh, this is 0.01
plus i divided by 100.
So that one would at the very least move.
So again, I've kind of done something
different than what I actually intended
to do when I started making this video tutorial.
And you could probably pause here and start
to play with this idea and think about different ways
that you might visualize this.
But I want to get back to talking
about the reason why I was here in the first place, which
is phase.
I want to see this graphed like a sine wave.
The way to do that is simply have a different starting
angle for each one of these dots.
For example, if this dot starts at angle 0,
its sine of 0 is in the 0 position.
Then this one might be slightly higher at angle 0.05, 0.1,
We'll start to see that graph play out.
Maybe I want to see the full sine wave
and make sure the starting angle here is 0
and the starting angle for this one is 2 pi.
Let's see what happens when I do that.
First thing first, let me take this out
so that now we're back to having just the circles flat
along the horizontal axis.
I want to give them a different starting angle.
Where is that starting angle?
What is that phase?
All of the starting angles are 0.
So I could say map i, which goes from 0 to total,
to between 0 and 2 pi.
And now you can see there is the graph of this sine function.
One full cycle through the wave from 0.
And for some reason, the way that I've drawn this,
I'm missing the last one.
So I might do something like add one extra one here.
And we can see I have that last one filled up
on the edge of the screen now.
Let me change the way I'm rendering
this to be a bit more clear.
I'm going to remove the line.
And I'm going to make r quite a bit smaller.
And we can see there are all the dots now graphing
that particular sine wave.
If I wanted a higher frequency wave,
if I wanted to see all the sine wave cycle through twice,
I could say, let's look at all the angles
from left to right between 0 and 4 pi, or 2 times 2 pi.
And now we can see there's two cycles of the wave.
Now, do I want this to be more like a graph?
There's a lot of space between these dots.
So here's where I could come down here and change
the way I'm rendering it.
And I could say begin shape, end shape, and vertex at x, y.
Oh, interestingly enough, it's got a fill to it.
So it's actually trying to make it a shape where
it actually fills things in.
I'm going to just take that out for right now.
I could also comment out the circle.
And there we go.
Now, what happens if I go back to this idea
of angular velocity?
What happens if I just add that back in?
Whoa.
So it's doing some crazy stuff.
Because again, I've got this weird, crazy pattern
of all of the dots also having a different period in frequency.
So I love this sort of strange, unexpected artifact
I got here.
Apologies for the flashing.
Now, I can go back and add in the idea
of incrementing each angle for each position as well.
Now, I encourage you to try variable increment values
like I had before.
You'll get also strange artifacts and patterns.
But I'm going to simplify things and just
have them move together, which ultimately ends up
giving the quality that makes it look like I
am panning across the wave.
Essentially, I'm sliding the wave across,
which is ultimately what I'm doing.
They're each starting at a different angle.
Then each angle changes.
It's like shifting the thing.
If I go back to rendering these as circles,
we can see once again, it looks as if these circles are
moving along this path.
But really, each one is just moving up and down
at exactly the same oscillation with a slight phase offset
from the one next to it.
So what might you do with this?
Hopefully, this is sparking some ideas in your head
about what kinds of visual patterns
you might try with different shapes and colors and periods
and ways of visualizing the wave patterns.
Certainly, could you create this wave pattern
around the perimeter of the circle?
In the way that I showed you how to use polar coordinates
to draw your own circular shape, could
you offset the various vertices of that circle
according to a sine wave?
The other thing, which is less of a creative output idea,
is that this isn't going to be super easy for me
to work with going forward.
I might want to do something where
I consider each one of these dots an object.
So maybe it stores position and angle and angle increment.
I'm not sure, but to package all of the idea of one of these
moving up and down into an object,
that's something that you might try to do.
Or perhaps the wave itself.
What is the starting angle?
What is the ending angle?
What is the phase offset?
What is the period?
What is the amplitude?
Whatever the properties are of a wave itself,
could you make a wave class?
And then you could make a bunch of different waves
simultaneously in the canvas just by making them as objects.
So I'll try to create some example solutions
to those exercise ideas.
You'll find those linked in the video's description.
But in the next video, what I actually want to demonstrate
is how to take this idea and turn it
into something like this.
What this is, is not just the result of graphing one wave,
but it's taking multiple sine waves, possibly cosine waves,
with different periods and different amplitudes
and adding them together, summing them
to get one resulting wave, an additive wave.
So that'll be the topic of the next video.
I'll take this example that we just did
and look at how to add multiple waves together to change,
to make a more dynamic pattern.
As always, if you've made something from this video,
check the link in the video's description
where you can share the results of what you made
on the Coding Train website.
OK?
See you in the next video, I hope.
Goodbye.
